values.title: Flaky segfault in FileLogger::Init during test

content.raw:
https://gist.github.com/scpeters/8b8a4facfffef5eb507f

Failure occurs during initialization of second test in [test/integration/gpu_laser.cc:213](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/dd709587a7b6/test/integration/gpu_laser.cc#gpu_laser.cc-213)

The ServerFixture constructor ([gazebo/test/ServerFixture.cc:84](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/dd709587a7b6/gazebo/test/ServerFixture.cc#ServerFixture.cc-84)) calls FileLogger::Init ([gazebo/common/Console.cc:203](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/dd709587a7b6/gazebo/common/Console.cc#Console.cc-203)) but has an error during allocation.
content.html:
https://gist.github.com/scpeters/8b8a4facfffef5eb507f

Failure occurs during initialization of second test in test/integration/gpu_laser.cc:213

The ServerFixture constructor (gazebo/test/ServerFixture.cc:84) calls FileLogger::Init (gazebo/common/Console.cc:203) but has an error during allocation.

values.title: Flaky race condition in INTEGRATION_joint_screw with simbody

content.raw:
Full details here: https://gist.github.com/scpeters/55690c29792ab7ffcc51

simbody threw an exception while
initializing the the `WorldState prevStates[2]` array inside `World::RunLoop`
[World.cc:485](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/81cc629155b9c682892ead799a918e9fdc6124dc/gazebo/physics/World.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#World.cc-485) array
initializing this state queries the state (position, velocity) of all models in links in the world

in a separate thread, `SetWorldPose` is called on a model
[joint_screw.cc:512](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/81cc629155b9c682892ead799a918e9fdc6124dc/test/integration/joint_screw.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#joint_screw.cc-512)
which calls `SimbodyLink::OnPoseChange`, which had probably changed the stage

cc @sherm1
content.html:
Full details here: https://gist.github.com/scpeters/55690c29792ab7ffcc51

simbody threw an exception while initializing the the WorldState prevStates[2] array inside World::RunLoop World.cc:485 array initializing this state queries the state (position, velocity) of all models in links in the world

in a separate thread, SetWorldPose is called on a model joint_screw.cc:512 which calls SimbodyLink::OnPoseChange, which had probably changed the stage

cc @sherm1

values.title: Flaky seg-fault in Connection::OnReadHeader during teardown

content.raw:
I've observed seg-faults from different tests with identical backtraces (details for 
[UNIT_Visual_TEST](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/b9c3c090d9603f165e66) and 
[UNIT_MagnetometerSensor_TEST](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/005c17e02b96955faa59)).
The seg-fault occurs during a `boost::asio::async_read` in `Connection::OnReadHeader`
([Connection.hh:259](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/81cc629155b9c/gazebo/transport/Connection.hh#Connection.hh-259)).

In the main thread, the test has completed and `ServerFixture::Unload` has been called during Teardown and is waiting for the server thread to join
([ServerFixture.cc:137](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/81cc629155b/gazebo/test/ServerFixture.cc#ServerFixture.cc-137)).

In the Server thread, `gazebo::shutdown` has been called at the end of `Server::Run`, which has called `ConnectionManager::Stop` and the thread is waiting in a loop for `ConnectionManager::stopped` to be true ([ConnectionManager.cc:250](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/81cc629155b9c6/gazebo/transport/ConnectionManager.cc#ConnectionManager.cc-249)).

cc @caguero
content.html:
I've observed seg-faults from different tests with identical backtraces (details for UNIT_Visual_TEST and UNIT_MagnetometerSensor_TEST). The seg-fault occurs during a boost::asio::async_read in Connection::OnReadHeader (Connection.hh:259).

In the main thread, the test has completed and ServerFixture::Unload has been called during Teardown and is waiting for the server thread to join (ServerFixture.cc:137).

In the Server thread, gazebo::shutdown has been called at the end of Server::Run, which has called ConnectionManager::Stop and the thread is waiting in a loop for ConnectionManager::stopped to be true (ConnectionManager.cc:250).

cc @caguero

values.title: Flaky race condition in UNIT_Visual_TEST during SetTransparency

content.raw:
I observed a seg-fault of `UNIT_Visual_TEST` during the `DerivedTransparency` test ([full details here](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/033c6c99b7ad0526a185707ac61b49d7)).

The main thread was calling `Visual::SetTransparency` ([Visual_TEST.cc:573](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a0e43939bd97680b/gazebo/rendering/Visual_TEST.cc#Visual_TEST.cc-573))
while the sensor thread was calling `ImageSensorContainer::Update`, `Scene::PreRender`, ... `Visual::GetShaderType`. These simultaneous calls lead to a seg-fault.
content.html:
I observed a seg-fault of UNIT_Visual_TEST during the DerivedTransparency test (full details here).

The main thread was calling Visual::SetTransparency (Visual_TEST.cc:573) while the sensor thread was calling ImageSensorContainer::Update, Scene::PreRender, ... Visual::GetShaderType. These simultaneous calls lead to a seg-fault.

values.title: Flaky OS X test failure: ModelManipulationTest.StopProcessingPoseMsgs

content.raw:
The `ModelManipulationTest.StopProcessingPoseMsgs` test [usually fails]() on OS X (gazebo7 and up) with the following error:

~~~
gazebo/gui/QTestFixture.cc:180 ::
 'resPercentChange < this->resMaxPercentChange' returned FALSE. ()
~~~

From the console output, it looks like the failing values are typically over 6.5, when the limit is 5:

~~~
439: ResPercentChange[6.75635]ResMaxPercentChange[5]
~~~

Is it appropriate to increase the threshold, or is this a sign of a problem?

values.title: Can't Set Joint State When Using Simbody

content.raw:
We have a plugin that we use to set joint position and velocity.  This works fine when our .world is using ODE.  However, this doesn't appear to work when we're using Simbody.  In verbose Gazebo output we see:
```
[Err] [SimbodyLink.cc:227] SetWorldPose (OnPoseChange) for child links need testing.
[Err] [SimbodyLink.cc:227] SetWorldPose (OnPoseChange) for child links need testing.
[Err] [SimbodyLink.cc:227] SetWorldPose (OnPoseChange) for child links need testing.
```

which was added [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/1007/implement-screw-joint-in-simbody-and-clean/diff#Lgazebo/physics/simbody/SimbodyLink.ccT221).  

The error isn't fatal.  Simulation continues, but nothing in the world changes as a result of the `SetWorldPose`.

values.title: QTestFixture can't write xml output if target path does not exist

content.raw: The tests all write junit xml files to the `test_results` folder in the build folder. The gtest and `check_test_ran` tests are able to create that folder if it doesn't exist, but QTestFixture does not create the folder. We generally don't see this problem since the gui tests don't run first when `make test` is called. This isn't a big deal, just something I ran into while working on flaky test detection.
content.html: The tests all write junit xml files to the test_results folder in the build folder. The gtest and check_test_ran tests are able to create that folder if it doesn't exist, but QTestFixture does not create the folder. We generally don't see this problem since the gui tests don't run first when make test is called. This isn't a big deal, just something I ran into while working on flaky test detection.

values.title: Camera Stops Sending Image Messages After World Reset

content.raw:
6.5.1

We have a Gazebo plugin that listens for certain messages, such as joint and camera image messages.  It's also capable of resetting the Gazebo world.

It appears after doing a world reset, we're no longer able to get messages from the camera.  Other messages, such as joint position, continue to be received as usual.

[Here](https://github.com/xanderdunn/storage/raw/master/gazebo/camera_after_reset.mov) is a screen recording of what I see:

To reproduce (Time in my video where this starts):

* Start an environment (0:00)
* Send messages to Gazebo to step x 50 (0:05)
* Notice that both the Gazebo GUI Image View and our plugin receive the camera image message successfully
* Send message to Gazebo to reset the world (1:05)
* Notice that the world correctly goes back to initial state.  
* Send a message to Gazebo to step (1:09)
* Notice that the plugin is stuck endlessly waiting for a camera image.
* Step through Gazebo using the GUI (since the plugin is blocked) (1:31)
* Notice that the GUI camera Image View doesn't update either

Choice of physics engine doesn't seem to be important.  We've reproduced this in both ODE and Simbody.  It's also not specific to this .world.  The behavior is identical in other environments we've built.

Do you have any thoughts on why doing a world reset would cause problems with the camera?  We're just using Gazebo's built-in camera model.
content.html:
6.5.1

We have a Gazebo plugin that listens for certain messages, such as joint and camera image messages. It's also capable of resetting the Gazebo world.

It appears after doing a world reset, we're no longer able to get messages from the camera. Other messages, such as joint position, continue to be received as usual.

Here is a screen recording of what I see:

To reproduce (Time in my video where this starts):

  • Start an environment (0:00)
  • Send messages to Gazebo to step x 50 (0:05)
  • Notice that both the Gazebo GUI Image View and our plugin receive the camera image message successfully
  • Send message to Gazebo to reset the world (1:05)
  • Notice that the world correctly goes back to initial state.
  • Send a message to Gazebo to step (1:09)
  • Notice that the plugin is stuck endlessly waiting for a camera image.
  • Step through Gazebo using the GUI (since the plugin is blocked) (1:31)
  • Notice that the GUI camera Image View doesn't update either

Choice of physics engine doesn't seem to be important. We've reproduced this in both ODE and Simbody. It's also not specific to this .world. The behavior is identical in other environments we've built.

Do you have any thoughts on why doing a world reset would cause problems with the camera? We're just using Gazebo's built-in camera model.

values.title: sdf image tag not well handle in gazebo

content.raw:
I am trying to use the sdf *image* tag in order to extrude wall from a png image. But it seems that something is broken in gazebo: no object appears (someone seems to have exactly the same problem here: http://answers.ros.org/question/196132/how-to-create-wall-in-gazebo-from-a-grayscale-image/ ).

in MapShape.cc we can see that the function 
void MapShape::CreateBoxes(QuadNode * /*_node*/)

is commented out, so I am guessing it's related ? What do you think ?

Maybee I am completly wrong, and not using the feature the right way.
content.html:
I am trying to use the sdf image tag in order to extrude wall from a png image. But it seems that something is broken in gazebo: no object appears (someone seems to have exactly the same problem here: http://answers.ros.org/question/196132/how-to-create-wall-in-gazebo-from-a-grayscale-image/ ).

Maybee I am completly wrong, and not using the feature the right way.

values.title: Flaky race condition in ~TimePanel

content.raw:
I observed a seg-fault in `TimePanel::OnStats` while `~TimePanel` was running in a separate thread ([backtrace and console output here](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/a07c2ae7f311a2a24939227db799cafd)). It complained about trying to lock a mutex. It turns out that the [order of variables in `TimePanelPrivate`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/2e6c0e3d3257bfc1f5ef1b61315edb2b771646dc/gazebo/gui/TimePanelPrivate.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#TimePanelPrivate.hh-53) causes the mutex to be destroyed before the `Subscriber`, so that the callback might be called after other private variables have been deleted.

I've been able to reproduce this error by adding a large delay to `~Subscriber` in  3a9e11d. I'm running that branch through jenkins to confirm the failure, and then I will commit a fix, starting with gazebo6 and merging forward.
content.html:
I observed a seg-fault in TimePanel::OnStats while ~TimePanel was running in a separate thread (backtrace and console output here). It complained about trying to lock a mutex. It turns out that the order of variables in TimePanelPrivate causes the mutex to be destroyed before the Subscriber, so that the callback might be called after other private variables have been deleted.

I've been able to reproduce this error by adding a large delay to ~Subscriber in 3a9e11d. I'm running that branch through jenkins to confirm the failure, and then I will commit a fix, starting with gazebo6 and merging forward.

values.title: Return unique pointers instead of raw pointers from factory functions

content.raw:
Consider a factory function that allocates memory and returns a raw pointer, such as `msgs::CreateRequest`:

~~~
msgs::Request *CreateRequest(const std::string &_request, const std::string &_data)
~~~

To communicate that ownership of the object is being passed, we should return a `unique_ptr`:

~~~
std::unique_ptr<msgs::Request> CreateRequest(const std::string &_request, const std::string &_data)
~~~
content.html:
Consider a factory function that allocates memory and returns a raw pointer, such as msgs::CreateRequest:

msgs::Request *CreateRequest(const std::string &_request, const std::string &_data)

To communicate that ownership of the object is being passed, we should return a unique_ptr:

std::unique_ptr<msgs::Request> CreateRequest(const std::string &_request, const std::string &_data)

values.title: Restructure the Model Editor entry and exit points

content.raw:
Users get confused about the Model Editor. They don't always know if they are in the ME, or in regular simulation mode. They don't always understand the difference between accessing the ME via the menu, and right-clicking a model to edit it in the ME.

When we tackle the Gazebo visual redesign, we should take this on as well. 

One idea is to make the ME more like the plotting utility, a separate window.

values.title: Make model insertion and variable plotting behavior consistent

content.raw:
Currently, models are adding by clicking/releasing and clicking again in the scene. In Plotting, users drag variables from the palette to the plot. These behaviors should be consistent.

I suggest making click/drag the default. This is the more standard interaction, and users often try to click/drag models to insert during testing sessions.

values.title: DART support for a link being child of two different joints

content.raw:
DART segfaults when destroying the world if there is a link which is the child of two different joints. This happens in the PR2 for example, but any simple model with 3 links and 2 joints is sufficient to trigger the problem:

```
#!xml


<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">
    <model name="box">
      <link name="link1" />
      <link name="link2" />
      <link name="link3" />
      <joint name="joint1" type="revolute">
        <parent>link1</parent>
        <child>link3</child>
        <axis>
          <xyz>1 0 0</xyz>
        </axis>
      </joint>
      <joint name="joint2" type="revolute">
        <parent>link2</parent>
        <child>link3</child>
        <axis>
          <xyz>0 1 0</xyz>
        </axis>
      </joint>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
```



This looks like an [upstream](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/671) issue.
content.html:
DART segfaults when destroying the world if there is a link which is the child of two different joints. This happens in the PR2 for example, but any simple model with 3 links and 2 joints is sufficient to trigger the problem:

<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">
    <model name="box">
      <link name="link1" />
      <link name="link2" />
      <link name="link3" />
      <joint name="joint1" type="revolute">
        <parent>link1</parent>
        <child>link3</child>
        <axis>
          <xyz>1 0 0</xyz>
        </axis>
      </joint>
      <joint name="joint2" type="revolute">
        <parent>link2</parent>
        <child>link3</child>
        <axis>
          <xyz>0 1 0</xyz>
        </axis>
      </joint>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>

This looks like an upstream issue.

values.title: Maybe improper usage of std::map[] in Master.cc

content.raw:
When checking whether connections exist and are open in the `MasterPrivate::connections` map, the following code is used:

~~~
if (!this->dataPtr->connections[_connectionIndex] ||
    !this->dataPtr->connections[_connectionIndex]->IsOpen())
~~~

The first statement will insert a new `ConnectionPtr` into the map if it doesn't already exist. Perhaps it should be:

~~~
if (this->dataPtr->connections.find(_connectionIndex) == this->dataPtr->connections.end() ||
    !this->dataPtr->connections[_connectionIndex] ||
    !this->dataPtr->connections[_connectionIndex]->IsOpen())
~~~

I found this while puzzling over the following backtrace from a gzserver running the simple_arm_test world as part of `UNIT_gz_TEST`:

~~~
#0  0x00002aca27319cc9 in __GI_raise (sig=sig@entry=6) at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c:56
#1  0x00002aca2731d0d8 in __GI_abort () at abort.c:89
#2  0x00002aca27312b86 in __assert_fail_base (fmt=0x2aca27463830 "%s%s%s:%u: %s%sAssertion `%s' failed.\n%n", assertion=assertion@entry=0x2aca25ab1b61 "px != 0", file=file@entry=0x2aca25ab23e8 "/usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp", line=line@entry=653, function=function@entry=0x2aca25ab4ec0 <boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::transport::Connection>::operator->() const::__PRETTY_FUNCTION__> "typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::transport::Connection; typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type = gazebo::transpor"...) at assert.c:92
#3  0x00002aca27312c32 in __GI___assert_fail (assertion=0x2aca25ab1b61 "px != 0", file=0x2aca25ab23e8 "/usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp", line=653, function=0x2aca25ab4ec0 <boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::transport::Connection>::operator->() const::__PRETTY_FUNCTION__> "typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::transport::Connection; typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type = gazebo::transpor"...) at assert.c:101
#4  0x00002aca25aa83b3 in boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::transport::Connection>::operator-> (this=<optimized out>) at /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:653
#5  0x00002aca25aaa64b in operator-> (this=<optimized out>) at gazebo/Master.cc:373
#6  gazebo::Master::ProcessMessage (this=this@entry=0x17fc530, _connectionIndex=3, _data=...) at gazebo/Master.cc:181
#7  0x00002aca25aab0ff in gazebo::Master::RunOnce (this=this@entry=0x17fc530) at gazebo/Master.cc:403
#8  0x00002aca25aab248 in gazebo::Master::Run (this=0x17fc530) at gazebo/Master.cc:381
#9  0x00002aca26b74a60 in ?? () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6
#10 0x00002aca287ba182 in start_thread (arg=0x2aca49560700) at pthread_create.c:312
#11 0x00002aca273dd47d in clone () at ../sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/clone.S:111
~~~
content.html:
When checking whether connections exist and are open in the MasterPrivate::connections map, the following code is used:

if (!this->dataPtr->connections[_connectionIndex] ||
    !this->dataPtr->connections[_connectionIndex]->IsOpen())

The first statement will insert a new ConnectionPtr into the map if it doesn't already exist. Perhaps it should be:

if (this->dataPtr->connections.find(_connectionIndex) == this->dataPtr->connections.end() ||
    !this->dataPtr->connections[_connectionIndex] ||
    !this->dataPtr->connections[_connectionIndex]->IsOpen())

I found this while puzzling over the following backtrace from a gzserver running the simple_arm_test world as part of UNIT_gz_TEST:

values.title: Model Editor: Nested links show up in schematic view before being inserted

content.raw:
For links it works properly:

1. On the left panel, click on the box
2. The box moves with the mouse in the 3D view, and does not show in the schematic view yet.
3. Click on the 3D scene, the box is released from the mouse and shows up in the schematic view.

But for nested models:


1. On the left panel, click on a model, such as `cabinet`
2. The model moves with the mouse in the 3D view, **but it already shows in the schematic view**.
3. Click on the 3D scene, the model is released from the mouse and remains in the schematic view.
content.html:
For links it works properly:

  1. On the left panel, click on the box
  2. The box moves with the mouse in the 3D view, and does not show in the schematic view yet.
  3. Click on the 3D scene, the box is released from the mouse and shows up in the schematic view.

But for nested models:

  1. On the left panel, click on a model, such as cabinet
  2. The model moves with the mouse in the 3D view, but it already shows in the schematic view.
  3. Click on the 3D scene, the model is released from the mouse and remains in the schematic view.

values.title: World::Stop not thread-safe, causes flaky test failure

content.raw:
I caught a backtrace of `INTEGRATION_world_remove` that complained about a double free ([details here](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/59fc84390ac0f2e3de32972a5117ae46)).

The memory access error occured in the `ServerFixture::RunServer` thread:

* `ServerFixture::RunServer` called
* [Server::Run](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/b016c48c/gazebo/Server.cc#Server.cc-567) which called
* `gazebo::shutdown` which called
* `World::Stop` which failed at
[line 460](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/b016c48c/gazebo/physics/World.cc#Server.cc-460)
when trying to delete the `WorldPrivate::thread`

In the main thread, the test called `physics::remove_worlds` at
[world_remove.cc:109](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/b016c48c/test/integration/world_remove.cc#world_remove.cc-109)
and was in the middle of `World::Fini` just after calling `World::Stop`
([line 832](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/b016c48c/gazebo/physics/World.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#World.cc-832)).
So it seems that `World::Stop` is not thread-safe.
content.html:
I caught a backtrace of INTEGRATION_world_remove that complained about a double free (details here).

The memory access error occured in the ServerFixture::RunServer thread:

  • ServerFixture::RunServer called
  • Server::Run which called
  • gazebo::shutdown which called
  • World::Stop which failed at line 460 when trying to delete the WorldPrivate::thread

In the main thread, the test called physics::remove_worlds at world_remove.cc:109 and was in the middle of World::Fini just after calling World::Stop (line 832). So it seems that World::Stop is not thread-safe.

values.title: Setting GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH overrides the compile-time default

content.raw:
By default, plugins shipped with Gazebo work without the need to set extra environment variables. For example, insert `Submarine (buoyant)` from the insert tab and it floats.

But when you want to use custom plugins and set the `GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH` environment variable, for example:

~~~
export GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH=`pwd`:$GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH
~~~

Then the default plugins stop working. Trying to insert the submarine now prints this message:

`[Err] [Plugin.hh:165] Failed to load plugin libBuoyancyPlugin.so: libBuoyancyPlugin.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`

This is because, if `GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH` is set, we ignore the compile-time path, in [SystemPaths::UpdatePluginPaths()](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/b3f5de12b2fa8695affd9ee2fc67dbb3d9c81b6e/gazebo/common/SystemPaths.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#SystemPaths.cc-251)
content.html:
By default, plugins shipped with Gazebo work without the need to set extra environment variables. For example, insert Submarine (buoyant) from the insert tab and it floats.

But when you want to use custom plugins and set the GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH environment variable, for example:

export GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH=`pwd`:$GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH

Then the default plugins stop working. Trying to insert the submarine now prints this message:

[Err] [Plugin.hh:165] Failed to load plugin libBuoyancyPlugin.so: libBuoyancyPlugin.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

This is because, if GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH is set, we ignore the compile-time path, in SystemPaths::UpdatePluginPaths()

values.title: Make it possible to add paths through the GUI

content.raw:
If you want to use the GUI to insert a model from a path that is not specified, you'd need to close Gazebo, add the path to `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` and open gazebo again. 

It would be nice to be able to add a path to the insert tab after Gazebo has been opened. Maybe just a browse button inside the insert tab like this:

![addpathbutton.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2800305863-addpathbutton.png)

A call to [gazebo::common::SystemPaths::Instance()->AddModelPathsUpdate(<dir>);](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0dea91f632c6e9d2b02639cb92fbb416da66a526/gazebo/common/SystemPaths.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#SystemPaths.hh-139) should be enough to update the tab.
content.html:
If you want to use the GUI to insert a model from a path that is not specified, you'd need to close Gazebo, add the path to GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH and open gazebo again.

It would be nice to be able to add a path to the insert tab after Gazebo has been opened. Maybe just a browse button inside the insert tab like this:

A call to gazebo::common::SystemPaths::Instance()->AddModelPathsUpdate(<dir>); should be enough to update the tab.

values.title: 0s converted to -0s in sdf when using model editor

content.raw: I edited one value in my model through the model editor, but some 0s were converted to -0s and a namespace tag was added. Expected behavior was just a diff of 1 line. Observed diff attached.
content.html: I edited one value in my model through the model editor, but some 0s were converted to -0s and a namespace tag was added. Expected behavior was just a diff of 1 line. Observed diff attached.

values.title: Model editing using factory message

content.raw:
The factory message has an [`edit_name`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/86f56413ee8f0a656982353c54f1347d4b716b68/gazebo/msgs/factory.proto?fileviewer=file-view-default) field which can be used to specify a model to be updated according to the SDF passed by the message.

The problem is that not all edits are supported and one needs to dig into the code to figure out what should work or not. We should improve the documentation of this feature, clearly defining its intended use. It's also necessary to add tests and fix the bits which are not working.
content.html:
The factory message has an edit_name field which can be used to specify a model to be updated according to the SDF passed by the message.

The problem is that not all edits are supported and one needs to dig into the code to figure out what should work or not. We should improve the documentation of this feature, clearly defining its intended use. It's also necessary to add tests and fix the bits which are not working.

values.title: Model snap tool - clicking on visual doesn't always highlight triangle

content.raw:
To reproduce:

1. insert two models, e.g. box and sphere

1. click on snap icon in toolbar

1. pick a triangle on sphere -> works fine

1. Press ESC to cancel

1. click on snap icon in toolbar again

1. pick a triangle on box -> works fine

1. repeat the last 3 steps - > no triangle is highlighted on box
content.html:
To reproduce:

  1. insert two models, e.g. box and sphere

  2. click on snap icon in toolbar

  3. pick a triangle on sphere -> works fine

  4. Press ESC to cancel

  5. click on snap icon in toolbar again

  6. pick a triangle on box -> works fine

  7. repeat the last 3 steps - > no triangle is highlighted on box

values.title: Mouse picking problem with transparent visuals

content.raw: When two transparent visuals overlap in the view of the use camera, mouse clicks some times pick the visual at the back instead of the one closer to the camera. Happens more often in translate mode.
content.html: When two transparent visuals overlap in the view of the use camera, mouse clicks some times pick the visual at the back instead of the one closer to the camera. Happens more often in translate mode.

values.title: Reset world freezes server in Simbody when models overlap

content.raw:
to reproduce:

1. gazebo -u -e simbody

1. insert box

1. insert another box that overlaps with the first one

1. Press play - no response
content.html:
to reproduce:

  1. gazebo -u -e simbody

  2. insert box

  3. insert another box that overlaps with the first one

  4. Press play - no response

values.title: TimePanel_TEST failure on r2d2

content.raw:
The TimePanel_TEST [fails consistently on r2d2](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/383/testReport/(root)/TimePanel_TEST/SpaceBar/) with the following error message:

~~~
gazebo/gui/TimePanel_TEST.cc:80 :: 'timePanel->IsPaused()' returned FALSE. ()
~~~

The TimePanel adds a [callback whenever the space key is pressed](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/5117a1c87ba5f612bca9b78cfd1cce5dd4df11c5/gazebo/gui/TimePanel.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#TimePanel.cc-91), and after adding some debugging print statements in 5117a1c, it appears that the keyboard callbacks aren't being called.
content.html:
The TimePanel_TEST fails consistently on r2d2 with the following error message:

gazebo/gui/TimePanel_TEST.cc:80 :: 'timePanel->IsPaused()' returned FALSE. ()

The TimePanel adds a callback whenever the space key is pressed, and after adding some debugging print statements in 5117a1c, it appears that the keyboard callbacks aren't being called.

values.title: Add ability to set IMU initial Orientation on boot

content.html:
Current implementation ImuSensor::SetReferencePose() is inadequate for typical simulation use.

Users desire the ability to specify what ImuSensor::Orientation() returns after the sensor is created in the world.

The reason being some of the existing IMU sensors in the market returns it's own frame orientation in the NED frame upon boot up, and the ability to do this is in simulation is critical. With existing API, the user would have to first rotate IMU to align with NED frame before calling ImuSensor::SetReferencePose.

Proposed solution here is to add

      /// \brief Sets the current reported pose of the IMU
      /// Replaces SetReferencePose.
      /// \param _orientation current IMU reported orientation
      public: void SetReferenceOrientation(
        const ignition::math::Quaterniond &_orientation =
        ignition::math::Quaterniond());

values.title: Escape should cancel model manipulation tools (move, rotate, scale)

content.raw:
Currently the model manipulation tools do not take effect until the mouse button is released, but there is no way to cancel the action once the mouse button has been pressed. It would be nice to be able to cancel an operation by pressing the escape key.

I don't know if it should switch to selection mode or just cancel the operation.

values.title: Resize tool doesn't account for frame rotations

content.raw: The `ModelManipulator` provides resize functionality in the sim window, but it doesn't properly account for frame rotations. An example world [pose_rotations.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/903144853fd50bb1125bbc165bd27d10ca2a344b/test/worlds/pose_rotations.world) is provided in 9031448 with a reference model and  models that will not resize correctly.
content.html: The ModelManipulator provides resize functionality in the sim window, but it doesn't properly account for frame rotations. An example world pose_rotations.world is provided in 9031448 with a reference model and models that will not resize correctly.

values.title: QTests with modal dialogs failing on Jenkins

content.raw:
`UNIT_CollisionConfig_TEST` and `UNIT_VisualConfig_TEST` open modal dialogs when a collision/visual is going to be deleted.

Locally, the test passes by triggering a `Key_Enter` signal to close the focused dialog (see commit  ac843cb). But this is consistently failing on Jenkins. 

The current workaround is to disable the dialog during tests.
content.html:
UNIT_CollisionConfig_TEST and UNIT_VisualConfig_TEST open modal dialogs when a collision/visual is going to be deleted.

Locally, the test passes by triggering a Key_Enter signal to close the focused dialog (see commit ac843cb). But this is consistently failing on Jenkins.

The current workaround is to disable the dialog during tests.

values.title: Using transparent, pre-defined materials causes memory leak

content.raw:
Hi Guys,

i have recognized a very strange behaviour caused by one of my robot models: Having both, gzclient and gzserver, running the necessary RAM increases more and more until the whole system begins to stutter due to memory swapping. By several checks, we have verified, that this only happens if gzclient is running and the model is within the view frustrum of gzclient's virtual camera.

I tried to isolate the error by removing parts of my robot piece by piece. Finally, i've figured out, that this is caused by using transparent materials in a link's visual definition:

```
#!xml
 <visual name='Redglass_Mesh'>
        <pose>0.25 0 .25 0 0 1.5707</pose>
        <transparency>0.0</transparency>
        <geometry><mesh><uri>model://path/to/meshes/mesh.stl</uri></mesh></geometry>
        <material>
          <script>
            <uri>file://media/materials/scripts/gazebo.material</uri>
            <name>Gazebo/RedTransparent</name>
          </script>
        </material>
      </visual>
```
Replacing the material with a non-transparent color fixes the issue. 
In our case, we have replaced the material name *RedTransparent* with *Red*  to 
avoid the memory leak successfully.

This issue occurs on debian-packaged Gazebo 6.5.1 as well as Gazebo 6.6 on Ubuntu 14.04 on several CPU/GPU combinations.

Best regards!
content.html:
Hi Guys,

i have recognized a very strange behaviour caused by one of my robot models: Having both, gzclient and gzserver, running the necessary RAM increases more and more until the whole system begins to stutter due to memory swapping. By several checks, we have verified, that this only happens if gzclient is running and the model is within the view frustrum of gzclient's virtual camera.

I tried to isolate the error by removing parts of my robot piece by piece. Finally, i've figured out, that this is caused by using transparent materials in a link's visual definition:

 <visual name='Redglass_Mesh'>
        <pose>0.25 0 .25 0 0 1.5707</pose>
        <transparency>0.0</transparency>
        <geometry><mesh><uri>model://path/to/meshes/mesh.stl</uri></mesh></geometry>
        <material>
          <script>
            <uri>file://media/materials/scripts/gazebo.material</uri>
            <name>Gazebo/RedTransparent</name>
          </script>
        </material>
      </visual>

Replacing the material with a non-transparent color fixes the issue. In our case, we have replaced the material name RedTransparent with Red to avoid the memory leak successfully.

This issue occurs on debian-packaged Gazebo 6.5.1 as well as Gazebo 6.6 on Ubuntu 14.04 on several CPU/GPU combinations.

Best regards!

values.title: Camera Noise Does Not Obey Global Seed

content.raw:
Gazebo 7.0.0.

When we send a `reset_world` message to Gazebo, we set the seed to a fixed value.  

On two separate runs, given the same actions, we see exactly the same result in Gazebo.  That is, our model joint positions are completely identical.  However:

Inside our world file we have a Gazebo built-in camera model with:
```
#!xml

            <noise>
              <type>gaussian</type>
              <mean>0</mean>
              <stddev>0.007</stddev>
            </noise>
```

Despite our global seed being the same, the images generated by this camera will be different on every run.

If the <noise> clause is removed, the images become deterministic and are identical across runs.

It appears the camera image noise generator does not make use of the Gazebo global seed.
content.html:
Gazebo 7.0.0.

When we send a reset_world message to Gazebo, we set the seed to a fixed value.

On two separate runs, given the same actions, we see exactly the same result in Gazebo. That is, our model joint positions are completely identical. However:

Inside our world file we have a Gazebo built-in camera model with:

            <noise>
              <type>gaussian</type>
              <mean>0</mean>
              <stddev>0.007</stddev>
            </noise>

Despite our global seed being the same, the images generated by this camera will be different on every run.

If the <noise> clause is removed, the images become deterministic and are identical across runs.

It appears the camera image noise generator does not make use of the Gazebo global seed.

values.title: Camera Output Appears to Depend on Real World Time

content.raw:
Gazebo 7.0.0. 

We start Gazebo paused and take each step by sending the message that's sent by `gz world -s`.  At a rate of 20 steps/s (as measured in real world time), we see consistent joint state and camera images across all runs.  

However, if this rate is slowed down to 10 steps/s or slower, we see the camera images become different from our faster runs despite the joint states being identical on each step.  As a trivial example, simply sleep for 1 second between each step.  The joint states remain unaffected by the sleep: they are identical across all runs.  However, the images from this slower run are different from the images in the 20 steps/s run.  We wouldn't expect any aspect of the simulation to be affected by time spent paused between steps.

Note that images are not compared visually, but at the level of the array values.  Values differ significantly:
```
[[[ 0.02885249]
  [ 0.02885249]
  [ 0.02885249]
  ...,
```
vs
```
[[[ 0.03031733]
  [ 0.03031733]
  [ 0.03031733]
  ...,
```

Note that this is *without* the camera noise mentioned in #1965.  

This is a significant problem for us because varying degrees of computational load or computational complexity produce inconsistent results.

I have this set up such that it's easily reproducible, so let me know if there are any helpful experiments I can perform.
content.html:
Gazebo 7.0.0.

We start Gazebo paused and take each step by sending the message that's sent by gz world -s. At a rate of 20 steps/s (as measured in real world time), we see consistent joint state and camera images across all runs.

However, if this rate is slowed down to 10 steps/s or slower, we see the camera images become different from our faster runs despite the joint states being identical on each step. As a trivial example, simply sleep for 1 second between each step. The joint states remain unaffected by the sleep: they are identical across all runs. However, the images from this slower run are different from the images in the 20 steps/s run. We wouldn't expect any aspect of the simulation to be affected by time spent paused between steps.

Note that images are not compared visually, but at the level of the array values. Values differ significantly:

[[[ 0.02885249]
  [ 0.02885249]
  [ 0.02885249]
  ...,

vs

[[[ 0.03031733]
  [ 0.03031733]
  [ 0.03031733]
  ...,

Note that this is without the camera noise mentioned in #1965.

This is a significant problem for us because varying degrees of computational load or computational complexity produce inconsistent results.

I have this set up such that it's easily reproducible, so let me know if there are any helpful experiments I can perform.

values.title: Features of protobuf 2.6

content.raw:
In pull request #2304, the [any.proto](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0f26a227e900a478cf8e846ea71c15476558b4dc/gazebo/msgs/any.proto) message is proposed (and has [already been merged into ign-msgs](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/10/messages-for-introspection/diff)). As noted in a [design document](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/annotate/f864f029fdd15347e6bbb4e2e46c6ce84e56a9ec/physics_params/physics_params.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#physics_params.md-109), protobuf 2.6 supports a `oneof` construct, which would be a more elegant way to implement he `any.proto` message.

Protobuf 2.6 is in homebrew, Ubuntu Wily and Xenial, but not trusty. Are we going to support trusty for gazebo8? ROS K is not supporting trusty for reference. If not, I would propose starting to use some protobuf 2.6 features.
content.html:
In pull request #2304, the any.proto message is proposed (and has already been merged into ign-msgs). As noted in a design document, protobuf 2.6 supports a oneof construct, which would be a more elegant way to implement he any.proto message.

Protobuf 2.6 is in homebrew, Ubuntu Wily and Xenial, but not trusty. Are we going to support trusty for gazebo8? ROS K is not supporting trusty for reference. If not, I would propose starting to use some protobuf 2.6 features.

values.title: event::Events::step and event::Events::stop never called

content.raw:
Reading source at tag gazebo7_7.1.0

gazebo / common / Events.hh 298-304 defines events for simulation "stop", "step" and "pause".

gazebo / physics / World.cc 155 even connects a handler to the "step" event.

However in the entire source tree I couldn't find a single call to event::Events::step(), meaning that the event is probably never triggered.

In fact, the step handler routine in World.cc is being called **directly** from World::OnControl() (line 1295), bypassing the event mechanism entirely.

The same applies to the "stop" event except that it's neither hooked nor triggered by any code.

I suppose that events were put there in the first place to allow plugins to hook them, but this is rather pointless when they're never triggered.

values.title: Model Editor: Error on press-to-select->drag to scale

content.raw:
1. Open model editor, insert a box

1. Select scale mode on the top toolbar

1. Press the mouse on the box (don't release the button)

1. Press the X key (keep on pressing together with the mouse)

1. Drag the mouse, and you get a stream of errors:

`[Err] [ModelManipulator.cc:432] Incorrect number of child visuals to be scaled. This should not happen`

That happens because the number of children in `mouseMoveVis` is counted before the `selectionObj` is attached to it.
content.html:
1. Open model editor, insert a box

  2. Select scale mode on the top toolbar

  3. Press the mouse on the box (don't release the button)

  4. Press the X key (keep on pressing together with the mouse)

  5. Drag the mouse, and you get a stream of errors:

[Err] [ModelManipulator.cc:432] Incorrect number of child visuals to be scaled. This should not happen

That happens because the number of children in mouseMoveVis is counted before the selectionObj is attached to it.

values.title: Camera sensor does not always publish to `~/sensor` on Init

content.raw:
to reproduce:

1. insert camera - camera visual appears in client  (means gzclient received a sensor msg on `~/sensor`) - works as expected

1. open topic viewer and select `/gazebo/default/sensor` to monitor sensor msgs

1. delete camera

1. insert camera again - no camera visual appears in client and topic viewer shows no msgs are published to `~/sensor`  - error!

1. insert more cameras - now they work as expected and sensor msgs are published

This issue seems to only happen when there are no other sensors in the scene and it only affects camera sensors.
content.html:
to reproduce:

  1. insert camera - camera visual appears in client (means gzclient received a sensor msg on ~/sensor) - works as expected

  2. open topic viewer and select /gazebo/default/sensor to monitor sensor msgs

  3. delete camera

  4. insert camera again - no camera visual appears in client and topic viewer shows no msgs are published to ~/sensor - error!

  5. insert more cameras - now they work as expected and sensor msgs are published

This issue seems to only happen when there are no other sensors in the scene and it only affects camera sensors.

values.title: changed the calculation of force/torque on parent link for ODEJoint::GetForceTorque()

content.html:
This was initially submitted as pull request #2110 by @vorndamme though it did not include a test, so it was moved to this issue while a test is written.

Original description:

Changed calculation of parent link force/torque. Force on child is calculated in world frame (was child frame before), where the parent force/torque can simply be the negative of the child force/torque (before, parent force/torque was set to the negative child force/torque, which was specified in child link frame and was added to the overall torque in parent link frame). Now all torques are calculated in world frame, summed up and transformed into child and parent frame in the end.

patch:

diff -r 17b2f08327b287ad319132729d19dffef097cb4e -r d989c13ef2a4f7d9c551ba09872eb3ce5b658c48 gazebo/physics/ode/ODEJoint.cc
--- a/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEJoint.cc
+++ b/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEJoint.cc
@@ -677,10 +677,10 @@
     physics::JointWrench wrenchAppliedWorld;
     if (this->HasType(physics::Base::HINGE_JOINT))
     {
-      // rotate force into child link frame
-      // GetLocalAxis is the axis specified in parent link frame!!!
+      // get torque on child in world frame, torque on parent acts in opposite
+      // direction
       wrenchAppliedWorld.body2Torque =
-        this->GetForce(0u) * this->GetLocalAxis(0u);
+        this->GetForce(0u) * this->GetGlobalAxis(0u);

       // gzerr << "body2Torque [" << wrenchAppliedWorld.body2Torque
       //       << "] axis [" << this->GetLocalAxis(0u)
@@ -690,9 +690,10 @@
     }
     else if (this->HasType(physics::Base::SLIDER_JOINT))
     {
-      // rotate force into child link frame
+      // get force on child in world frame, force on parent acts in opposite
+      // direction
       wrenchAppliedWorld.body2Force =
-        this->GetForce(0u) * this->GetLocalAxis(0u);
+        this->GetForce(0u) * this->GetGlobalAxis(0u);
       wrenchAppliedWorld.body1Force = -wrenchAppliedWorld.body2Force;
     }
     else if (this->HasType(physics::Base::FIXED_JOINT))
@@ -705,6 +706,8 @@
       gzerr << "force torque for joint type [" << this->GetType()
             << "] not implemented, returns false results!!\n";
     }
+    // add wrench in world frame before transform into child and parent frame
+    this->wrench = this->wrench + wrenchAppliedWorld;

     // convert wrench from child cg location to child link frame
     if (this->childLink)
@@ -848,7 +851,6 @@
           this->wrench.body1Torque);
       }
     }
-    this->wrench = this->wrench - wrenchAppliedWorld;
   }
   else
   {

values.title: Problems in UNIT_gz_TEST

content.html:
While debugging a regression of gzTest.Model after pull request #2301 was merged, I found some weird issues with other parts of the test.

First of all, all of the tests in this file load test/worlds/simple_arm_test.world, but upon inspection, this world file was not being loaded, and the simple_arm model was not present. I believe this is caused by the incorrect use of execlp, which should have the gzserver argument repeated twice. The following patch causes this world to be loaded, but the test is very broken when this happens.

diff -r 5bcd2fe9e326 tools/gz_TEST.cc
--- a/tools/gz_TEST.cc  Tue Jun 07 16:00:03 2016 -0700
+++ b/tools/gz_TEST.cc  Tue Jun 07 17:50:43 2016 -0700
@@ -97,7 +97,7 @@
   {
     boost::filesystem::path worldFilePath = TEST_PATH;
     worldFilePath = worldFilePath / "worlds" / "simple_arm_test.world";
-    if (execlp("gzserver", worldFilePath.string().c_str(),
+    if (execlp("gzserver", "gzserver", worldFilePath.string().c_str(),
         "--iters", "60000", NULL) < 0)
     {
       gzerr << "Failed to start the gazebo server.\n";

values.title: It's not possible to change rendering::Grid's line thickness

content.raw:
The `rendering::Grid` class has a `SetLineWidth` function and takes a line width parameter in its constructor, but the thickness is not being used when creating the grid.

After researching a bit it seems that Ogre lines always have a 1 px thickness, but I might be wrong. One way of going around this might be by using billboards instead of lines. Otherwise, we should consider deprecating grid line width.
content.html:
The rendering::Grid class has a SetLineWidth function and takes a line width parameter in its constructor, but the thickness is not being used when creating the grid.

After researching a bit it seems that Ogre lines always have a 1 px thickness, but I might be wrong. One way of going around this might be by using billboards instead of lines. Otherwise, we should consider deprecating grid line width.

values.title: Any reason why World::GetModels()  copy constructs instead of returning a reference?

content.html:
I can't think of any scenario where this

Model_V World::GetModels() const
{
  return this->dataPtr->models;
}

is preferable to:

Model_V const & World::GetModels() const
{
  return this->dataPtr->models;
}

The former is a forced waste of CPU cycles for copying a bunch of ModelPtrs. Since these are smart shared pointers, this also means incrementing reference counts for all models when the copy is made and decrementing them again when the copied vector is discarded, which expectably is very shortly afterwards.

For comparison, we do have const Model_V & Model::NestedModels() const

Issue marked for version 6.0 for lack of a more recent option, but is present at the repository tip as well.

values.title: LogicalCamera.cc does not implement Topic() function

content.raw: Only GetTopic() is implemented but in the Load function, Topic() is called which resolves to sensor::Topic that takes the argument from the sdf. This is different from for example the RaySensor.

values.title: Moving the center of gravity of a link with joints results in false forces (ODE).

content.html:
In Gazebo 7, when I programatically move the CoG of a link that is connected via joints to other links, the model "freaks out", flies away, and... you know that :) I do the moving in a model plulgin's Load method, when the simulation is paused (before the very first simulation step).

I've done a lot of tests, tried changing the CoG using (at least) these methods:

1)

math::Pose pose;
pose.pos.x = -1.0;
physics::Inertial in = model->GetChildLink(link)->GetInertial()->GetInertial(pose);
*model->GetChildLink(link)->GetInertial() = in;
model->GetChildLink(link)->UpdateMass();

2)

math::Pose pose = model->GetChildLink(link)->GetInertial()->GetPose();
pose.pos.x += -1.0;
model->GetChildLink(link)->GetInertial()->SetCoG(pose);
model->GetChildLink(link)->UpdateMass();

3)

msgs::Model msg;
msg.set_name(model->GetName());
msg.add_link();
auto msgLink = msg.mutable_link(0);
msgLink->set_name(link);
msgLink->set_id(odeLink2->GetId());
auto msgInertial = msgLink->mutable_inertial();
ignition::math::Vector3d newCoG(odeLink2->GetInertial()->GetCoG().Ign());
newCoG.X(newCoG.X() - 1.0);
msgs::Set(msgInertial->mutable_pose(), ignition::math::Pose3d(newCoG, ignition::math::Quaterniond()));
transport::PublisherPtr modelPub = gazeboNode->Advertise<msgs::Model>("~/model/modify");
modelPub->WaitForConnection();
modelPub->Publish(msg, true);

Maybe I also tried other methods, I don't remember.

When the link of which I'm changing the CoG is not connected with joints to other links, then the CoG moves as expected. When I specify a CoG offset in the SDF file (via <inertial><pose> tag), and then load the model, it works in both cases (with joints and without joints).

There are thus 4 cases:

  1. CoG set in SDF, joints (ok)
  2. CoG set in SDF, no joints (ok)
  3. CoG set at runtime, joints (not ok)
  4. CoG set at runtime, no joints (ok)

I think these 4 test cases demonstrate, that what I describe is actually a bug, and not a feature. I've created a failing unit test for this behavior (I'll reference the PR here in a while).

I gave it 3-4 days to debug what's happening, tried "fixing" every relative offset I've found (like the Link's SetRelativePose(), SetInitialRelativePose(), or the joints' anchors), I tried various physics resets (like world->ResetPhysicsStates() or world->Reset()) and so on, but I did not succeed finding the root cause. One thing is sure - the CoG always "wants to" move to its original location, and that's the false force that disturbs the simulation. After a while it succeds and happily resides in the original position, but the link is shifted (as you can see in the attached images).

I also tried using the Link->UpdateParameters and changing the offset in the Sdf, but it ended up with unrelated errors (probably another bug?). This piece of code:

sdf::ElementPtr linkSdf = link->GetSDF();
if (linkSdf->HasElement("inertial"))  {
    auto inertialElem = linkSdf->GetElement("inertial");
    auto pose = inertialElem->Get<math::Pose>("pose");
    pose.pos.x -= 1.0;
    inertialElem->Set(pose);
    odeLink->GetInertial()->UpdateParameters(inertialElem);
    // or odeLink->UpdateParameters(linkSdf);
}

ends up with error Missing description for the gravity element, and sometimes also with Could not find value for pose (but here I think I've found out that it is the link's pose, and not the inertial's pose, what's not found).

values.title: Parse SDF frame elements and attributes

content.raw:
Reference frames were added to SDF on [pull request 237](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/237/support-frame-specification-in-sdf/diff), according to [this](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/f864f029fdd15347e6bbb4e2e46c6ce84e56a9ec/sdf_reference_geometry/sdf_reference_geometry.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) design document.

However, Gazebo is currently just ignoring `<frame>` elements and attributes.

I marked this as critical because users have been asking about this, see for example [this](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/12752/frames-in-sdf-robot-model-how-to-define-relative-links/) question and [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issues/124/make-link-reference-frame-relative-to) issue. While this is not implemented, we should at least try to find a way to let users know whether an SDF tag is implemented.
content.html:
Reference frames were added to SDF on pull request 237, according to this design document.

However, Gazebo is currently just ignoring <frame> elements and attributes.

I marked this as critical because users have been asking about this, see for example this question and this issue. While this is not implemented, we should at least try to find a way to let users know whether an SDF tag is implemented.

Hi.
I tried to use openal.world with gazebo5 on Ubuntu 14.04, but I heard no sound, when a cube touched the ground plane.
After I found some past gazebo tracker documents, I tried moving the sphere which has a microphone at several places around the cube. But it did not give me any effects.

Now I am guessing that the sound system is not working in gazebo5.

Thanks.

values.title: Actors accept links and joints but not nested models

content.raw: `physics::Actor` inherits from `physics::Model`, but unlike the latter, it isn't possible to have nested models within an actor.
content.html: physics::Actor inherits from physics::Model, but unlike the latter, it isn't possible to have nested models within an actor.

values.title: Control actor animation via messages

content.raw:
It is possible to play, pause and set the actor animation script to a specific time, all from plugins, through the [physics::Actor](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/fc57cca085988f7a0c94183f97c1227bd8dfb017/gazebo/physics/Actor.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Actor.hh-91) API.

It would be nice to also expose these as a transport topic, so the animation can be controlled from the command line, clients, etc.
content.html:
It is possible to play, pause and set the actor animation script to a specific time, all from plugins, through the physics::Actor API.

It would be nice to also expose these as a transport topic, so the animation can be controlled from the command line, clients, etc.

values.title: Add tests and examples for BVH Loader (and fix it too?)

content.raw:
I tested loading BVH animation files from [this](https://accad.osu.edu/research/mocap/mocap_data.htm) project, but the BVH loader is returning a null skeleton on [this](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/5adf274c0172e4707ac86523c3aedd3d332f3c7c/gazebo/common/BVHLoader.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#BVHLoader.cc-154) line. 

Since there are no examples or tests for the BVH loader, it's hard to tell if it has ever worked.

It would be nice to answer [this](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/8977/how-can-i-use-bvh-loader/) question too.

The way I'm testing this is by using the BVH file as the animation file in [actor.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/5adf274c0172e4707ac86523c3aedd3d332f3c7c/worlds/actor.world?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#actor.world-18). I didn't expect the animation to be compatible with the collada skin straight away, but I was hoping at least that the `BVHLoader` would return a skeleton pointer containing animations.
content.html:
I tested loading BVH animation files from this project, but the BVH loader is returning a null skeleton on this line.

Since there are no examples or tests for the BVH loader, it's hard to tell if it has ever worked.

It would be nice to answer this question too.

The way I'm testing this is by using the BVH file as the animation file in actor.world. I didn't expect the animation to be compatible with the collada skin straight away, but I was hoping at least that the BVHLoader would return a skeleton pointer containing animations.

values.title: Give plot axes better labels

content.raw:
currently `x` is hard-coded to `Sim Time (seconds)` and `y` is `Variable values`

- Need to update x label when we support plotting arbitrary variables on the x-axis. 

- There is a suggestion to set y-axis label the name of the variable when only one variable is present, and switch back to `Variable values` when users add more variables to the plot
content.html:
currently x is hard-coded to Sim Time (seconds) and y is Variable values

  • Need to update x label when we support plotting arbitrary variables on the x-axis.

  • There is a suggestion to set y-axis label the name of the variable when only one variable is present, and switch back to Variable values when users add more variables to the plot

values.title: PID max and min command limits are hard coded around 0

content.raw:
[PID check against cmdMin and cmdMax](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/2943bf3e08f46ced48b46a0ec6726f2967a92942/gazebo/common/PID.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#PID.cc-154) is hardcoded around a zero command. In general, if one wishes to limit PID commands between a range not closed around 0, this class will have a hard time doing so.

For example, if I want the PID to issue commands between [-1, 0], these checks will fail to truncate max command if it goes above 0.
content.html:
PID check against cmdMin and cmdMax is hardcoded around a zero command. In general, if one wishes to limit PID commands between a range not closed around 0, this class will have a hard time doing so.

For example, if I want the PID to issue commands between [-1, 0], these checks will fail to truncate max command if it goes above 0.

values.title: Sonar only detect with edges of the cone

content.raw:
When implementing the void OnUpdate(gazebo::msgs::SonarStamped msg) callback of a gazebo::SonarPlugin, the msg.sonar().range() value is only valid when the edge of the sensor cone is being intersected by another surface.

Here is attached a world with an animated sphere that move through the sonar detection range. The necessary plugins are also attached.

This is observed with ODE. With Bullet, the two objects collide as reported in Issue #1038.
content.html:
When implementing the void OnUpdate(gazebo::msgs::SonarStamped msg) callback of a gazebo::SonarPlugin, the msg.sonar().range() value is only valid when the edge of the sensor cone is being intersected by another surface.

Here is attached a world with an animated sphere that move through the sonar detection range. The necessary plugins are also attached.

This is observed with ODE. With Bullet, the two objects collide as reported in Issue #1038.
